instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3662: What is 820-3662? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..
definitions.ADAPTER_EN: What is ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.ADPATER_EN: What is ADPATER_EN? This is a typo of SMC_ADAPTER_EN When you see ADPATER_EN, assume they meant to type SMC_ADAPTER_EN.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid
threads.message:
Liquid damage. Corrosion around <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>

Came in with no 3V42
Repaired <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> area, repaired <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>.
No green / orange.
Replaced SMC, now have green orange.

PPBUS 12.5
3V42 is 3V42
3V3V / 5V S5 is 3V3 and 5

No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5</SIGNAL>
No pulsing / cycling

PPVRTC is 3v3
<SIGNAL>CLK32_RTC</SIGNAL> is present

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> present? Used correct SMC from identical donor?

The SMC was probably killed by a voltage spike on 3V42 because of <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> damage. All parts on 3V42 rail are now suspect, <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>,<CHIP>U1950</CHIP>,<CHIP>U5110</CHIP> are the ones that will affect power on and may just as well be replaced all.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 35249"]<SIGNAL>ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> present? Used correct SMC from identical donor?

The SMC was probably killed by a voltage spike on 3V42 because of <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> damage. All parts on 3V42 rail are now suspect, <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>,<CHIP>U1950</CHIP>,<CHIP>U5110</CHIP> are the ones that will affect power on and may just as well be replaced all.[/QUOTE]

SMC, yes same board 3662
DSW present
Tried <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>,<CHIP>U1950</CHIP>,<CHIP>U5110</CHIP>

Green / Orange

No PM signals

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid
threads.message: Checked all rails for shorts? The SMC is a good suspect again of course. Did not see answer to <SIGNAL>ADPATER_EN</SIGNAL> present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 35257"]Checked all rails for shorts? The SMC is a good suspect again of course. Did not see answer to <SIGNAL>ADPATER_EN</SIGNAL> present.[/QUOTE]

Adapter enable is present.
SMC was pulled from a board with RAM failure, but I guess it could have been killed with heat but I'm not sure I've ever had that happen yet

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid
threads.message: You can try another SMC, but after that it may very well be a PCH problem :(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 35367"]You can try another SMC, but after that it may very well be a PCH problem :([/QUOTE]

Honestly, I got fed up ages ago and sold them a new Mac.

Thanks for your help though, Duke.
